item.title: [ROO-442] Provide multipart file upload support
item.description:
The generated Property Editor uses text field for byte[] property, it should use file browser instead (input type=file).

When enter 1000 to the property that its type is byte[], there is the error message as follows:

Failed to convert property value of type java.lang.String[] to required type byte[] for property image; nested exception is java.lang.NumberFormatException: Value out of range. Value:"1000" Radix:10

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment:
I've discussed this with Stefan and it is really an enhancement request so multipart file upload works OK. As we're about to release RC4, it's too late in the cycle to add it for the 1.0.0 series.

You are welcome to add support for multipart file upload in the normal Spring manner in the meantime. Roo scaffolding does not support it at present. By default we setup the CommonsMultipartResolver for you in the dispatcher servlet XML, so it's quite simple to write the relevant controller.
See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2190851/spring-file-upload-in-a-mixed-form for related tips in the meantime.
There is a related forum thread with a temp workaround for SPR-6594: http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?t=84889&page=2

Jose, I like your tutorial. We have done something similar on our project.
A note though, if you were to add Multipart filtering, then you shouldn't require any explicit binding in your Controller, it gets taken care of. To turn it on, you set the following.
(you still need the enctype="multipart/form-data" as in your multi.tagx)

eg.
applicationContext.xml
<bean id="multipartFilter" class="org.springframework.web.multipart.support.MultipartFilter">
<property name="multipartResolverBeanName" value="multipartResolver" />
</bean>

<bean id="multipartResolver" class="org.springframework.web.multipart.commons.CommonsMultipartResolver"/>

web.xml
<filter>
<filter-name>multipartFilter</filter-name>
<filter-class>org.springframework.web.filter.DelegatingFilterProxy</filter-class>
</filter>
<filter-mapping>
<filter-name>multipartFilter</filter-name>
<url-pattern>/*</url-pattern>
</filter-mapping>

Jose, I think your tutorial is great!

As Brad mentioned you can reduce your code a bit here and there by removing the binding logic.

Also, many users may want to store their pictures in the file system and just keep references to the locally stored files in the DB. This is especially important for larger blobs which would simply not be very suitable for relational databases.

It would be great to add this functionality as an external add-on.

Brad, Stefan,

Thank you very much for your comments on my tutorial...

On the alternative approach shown by Brad. I believe is one of those things that should be left to the Developer to decide.

Certainly you cut on a one line method. But you have to add configuration to others.

I see the convenience of the centralized configuration. If your web app does file uploads from multiple places.

Per Stefan suggestion, I am going to include the use-case for larger blobs and publish it part2 tutorial or something.
